awd_titl_txt: Enabling Milliarcsecond Astrophysics: Open access for the CHARA Array
awd_abstract_narration:
This program will provide observing time to the astronomical community using the Georgia State University Center for High Angular Resolution Astronomy (CHARA), as well as open access to archival CHARA data. Broader impacts of the work involve training of undergraduate and graduate students in instrumentation development, including a focused research opportunity for Georgia State undergraduates to participate in CHARA research.  This proposal will also help fund upgrades to the CHARA Exhibit Hall on Mt. Wilson, which illustrates interferometry to the general public via displays of historical equipment and explanations of how the current system works. 

CHARA operates an optical/near infrared (OIR) interferometric array on Mount Wilson, CA. The CHARA Array has six 1-m aperture telescopes in a Y configuration providing 15 baselines from 33 to 331 meters and ten independent closure phase triangles. With the number and size of its telescopes, its imaging capabilities, the length of its baselines, the range of wavelength regimes and spectral resolutions covered by its beam combiners, the CHARA Array is a uniquely powerful facility for milliarcsecond imaging. This proposal defines a path to move optical interferometry from a rather small and experimental group to a broader user community.

por.por_cntn:
The stars of the night sky are remote suns that appear faint because of their enormous distances. They appear simply as mathematical dots even in images made with the largest conventional telescopes.  The ability to "resolve" the stars and see them as full disks requires telescopes much larger than exist today.  Astronomers solve this problem by building arrays of distributed smaller telescopes that can act together like one huge telescope.  The CHARA Array is the largest such interferometric array in the world that operates at optical wavelengths.  It consists of six telescopes with 1 meter diameter mirrors that are spread across the grounds of the historic Mount Wilson Observatory, which is located in the San Gabriel Mountains north of Los Angeles (see figures).  This remarkable instrument can measure the sizes of stars as small as the apparent dimensions of a nickel coin as seen from a distance of 10,000 miles. 

The National Science Foundation award to the Georgia State University CHARA Array provided the means to open the facility to scientists from across the nation and around the world.  Proposals for observing programs were selected through a national peer-review process, and 278 nights were assigned to the successful programs over a period of five years. CHARA scientists assisted these guest astronomers in planning, making, and analyzing their observations.  The open access program was promoted through workshops and lectures at professional meetings and institutions across the U.S.  In addition, a complete data archive of past observations and analysis software was created at Georgia State University for use by the scientific community. 

The CHARA Array open access program has served in scientific investigations by hundreds of astronomers. These studies have revealed the detailed physical properties of stars and their environments including their radius, mass, temperature, age, and motion.  This information is key to understanding how stars and planets form, change over time, and eventually leave behind compact remnants such as white dwarfs, neutron stars, and black holes.  This forms the essential background to understanding our own Sun and its future path.  The scientific mission of the CHARA Array is central to the training of the next generation of scientists, and observations from the Array are the focus of graduate student dissertations at Georgia State University and elsewhere.  The Mount Wilson Observatory is a draw to thousands of visitors each year, and the CHARA Array invites these visitors to the CHARA Exhibit Hall in which a series of displays show how interferometry works to determine the sizes of the stars.
